body:
Several OSs have interfaces that could be used instead of a timing heuristic:
- iOS: [applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning](https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/ios/documentation/UIKit/Reference/UIApplicationDelegate_Protocol/index.html#//apple_ref/occ/intfm/UIApplicationDelegate/applicationDidReceiveMemoryWarning:)
- Android: [onLowMemory](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/ComponentCallbacks.html#onLowMemory())
- Windows: [CreateMemoryResourceNotification ](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa366541(v=vs.85).aspx)

What's missing is a Unix story. I wonder, has anyone ever tried to measure memory pressure by counting page faults? (I realize disk swap is unusual in servers, but with zswap becoming a thing maybe page faults aren't a useless signal.)
